here is my general advice for founders
and it doesn't usually change that much
this is the advice that I talked about

but there's another important component
to building a successful company which
is a challenge that every one of you in
this room
are going to face if you start one
building a great team and culture and
that's actually one of my areas of
expertise people and culture have always
played an important role at Y Combinator
from the very beginning and I was the
one responsible for these things from
the very beginning most people don't
know this both because I prefer to
operate in the background and because
people only know the version of YC that
they read about in the press they know
the structure of YC but not the people
it consists of and how they interact
softer stuff like values and culture and
community is often ignored by the press
and more dangerously it's sometimes
ignored by founders maybe that's because
it doesn't seem exciting or it's touchy
feely or it's really hard to measure or
maybe when you're trying to solve a
technical problem that's never been
solved before company culture seems a
secondary consideration but company
culture starts when it's just two people
working on an idea in the kitchen in my
experience the founders who start to
care about their culture the soonest
also tend to be the ones who build the
best companies in fact the reason why C
has deliberately never offered office
space to founders is precisely because
of this insight the founders of
individual startups drive the culture
from a very early stage and this culture
needs to grow organically in the
startups own space so today I'm going to
tell you a little bit about the origins
of Y Combinator's community and culture
that I've never really shared before one
of the reasons I've never talked about
it is that YCS culture was largely my
creation and I didn't want to seem to be
bragging but if you understand my story
you'll understand what Y Combinator
really is and I think it's important to
understand what YC really is because
while lots of people have
feed the structure of y combinator no
one else has successfully copied the
people part in my opinion y combinator
is two things one it's a new structure
of investment firm and two it's a
collection of people both founders and
partners the collection of people has
mostly been curated by me over the past
decade my co-founders Paul Robert and
Trevor are amazing at judging technical
ideas but as they'd be the first to
admit they're not as good judges of
character that's my department for some
reason I've always been a good judge of
character even as a little kid so during
the history of YC for the most part they
judge the ideas and I judge the people
my co-founders called me the social
radar for what seemed to them my uncanny
ability to see through fakers and
sociopaths but it's historically been
very important in making y see what it
is the last step in ycs funding
decisions are an in-person interview
with YC partners now we have five inner
interview tracks so I only see about
twenty percent of the applicants but for
the first seven years we had a single
interview track and I was always part of
it in fact my co-founders respected my
opinion about character so much that it
would be not far off to say that I had
veto over funding decisions most of the
people we interviewed didn't realize
that because I don't usually say much
during interviews what I do during
interviews is watch the typical
interview consisted of my co-founders
peppering the applicants with technical
questions while I watched how they
responded to them most applicants barely
even realized I was there
but after they walked out my partner's
would usually turn to me to get my read
on applicants as people I didn't always
understand that details of the questions
they'd asked and to this day I cannot
tell you about operating systems or
distributed databases but I can tell
things like when people are be essing or
how tough they are or if they get along
and surprisingly often considering I
only have 10 minutes to observe them
whether they're good people or not as I
said Paul Robert and Trevor are really
good at technical stuff but it's
precisely because they're so good that
they often misjudged founders as people
they'd get excited talking to the
applicants about all the different
things that they could do and then
afterward they think the interview went
well when sometimes all the applicants
did was reflect their own ideas back at
them but it was second nature to me to
notice these things countless times we
talked to a group of applicants and my
co-founders would say afterward they
seem good we should fund them and I'd
have to point out that all this group
did during the interview was not and say
yes when we suggested ideas to them it's
obvious why we'd want to fund founders
who are knowledgeable and determined but
i also found myself filtering for
character as well this was not a
deliberate decision I have a very
intense reaction to people who I think
have bad characters and this is probably
true for anyone who's a sensitive judge
of character just as anyone with a good
sense of smell would be bothered by a
particularly ripe dumpster on a summer
day before y combinator character was
not traditionally an important factor
for investors investors often funded
people who are jerks but you know they
might seem likely to succeed but I
couldn't do it YC is not just an
investment firm it's like a family and
that we're inviting these people all to
our place for dinner every week
but while this innovation was
unintentional or at least involuntary it
turned out to be super valuable for Y
Combinator as Y Z has grown an
increasing amount of the value is in the
alumni network now there are over 2,000
alumni and the fact that we've filtered
out most of the bad people means that
they're almost all nurturing and
trustworthy when newly funded YC
companies approached them starting a
start-up has traditionally been a really
lonely business so imagine what it means
for their to literally be 2,000 people
who will come to your aid if asked we
continue to filter for character even
now that we have five interview tracks
because now this has become part of YCS
culture and while we of course have made

meet a YC founder your meaning someone
you can trust they say that institutions
are the shadows of the founders and that
aspect of YC is part of my shadow
another area where I had a big effect is
the atmosphere of Y Combinator before YC
atmosphere was not something investment
firms even had they just had portfolios
but y si was different because after
selecting founders we brought them
together for dinner every week and
there's a very distinct atmosphere at YC
dinners if I had to put it into words
I'd use words like cheery collegial
supportive and energizing but it's one
of those things that's so remarkable
it's hard to put into words striped
co-founder Patrick Collison once said
that one of the best things about YC was
quote the buzz of walking into y
combinator on a Tuesday evening and the
general energy and excitement of the
founders that's what comes to mind for
me when I think of YC and it's what I
described to others when they asked why
they should do YC
end quote the atmosphere at YZ dinners
today is a direct descendant of the
atmosphere at the very first dinners we
had back in the summer of 2005 there
were only eight companies then I did the
grocery shopping and Paul did all the
cooking and our first headquarters was
in a building Paul owned and had been
using as his office so it felt as if we
were inviting people over to our house
every week we had a fireplace and I used
to build fires sometimes and i'd splurge
on fancy cheeses from a local gourmet
cheese shop it was basically a dinner
party for our friends this feeling has
inevitably been diluted as YC has grown
there are a hundred and sixteen startups
in this current batch and YC now has its
own 12,000 square foot building so can't
quite feel as much as if founders are
coming into our house over to our house
for dinner but it still feels a lot more
intimate than you would imagine an event
for a hundred and sixteen companies
could be one of the reasons it still
feels like home is it the same architect
who made our first headquarters has done
every state space since Kate quarto
she's part of the family and she knows
we want to keep that family feeling it's
amazing what she's been able to achieve
you walk into our new building and it's
simultaneously feels magnificent and
homey Paul wants wrote an essay called
do things that don't scale the idea is
that even if you want to be big when
you're small you should give your
customers a level of attention you can
only give them when you're small this
will set the standards for your customer
service very high and you'll be able to
maintain those standards better than you
might expect as you grow we followed our
own advice at YC and one of the most
important things we did that didn't
scale was to treat the founders as if
they were family
it was easy to do during that first
summer batch because there were so few
founders plus in the beginning the
founders were mostly young because they
were the only ones who'd apply to
something like YC so we literally felt
like their parents I knew where everyone
was from who their significant others
were and I worried about stuff like
whether they were getting enough
nutrients in their diet I did someone
got scurvy that summer actually is very
very upsetting perhaps even more
importantly we did not expect those
startups to make money YC has been so
successful successful since that it's
hard for people to realize but the first
batch of startups we funded was just for
us to learn how to be investors we
quickly realized that that funding
startups and batches was a great idea
and that we should do all of our
investing that way but the first batch
was just an experiment that we expected
to lose money on and since we thought of
that first badge as a sort of nonprofit
social project it affected the way we
acted toward the founders it was natural
for us when advising the companies just
to ask what's best for the founders even
our original investment paperwork was
novel in how found her friendly the
terms were we didn't ask for any special
powers that investors normally do and we
still don't this is actually one of
those counterintuitive things about
startups but one of the keys to being
successful is not to be to immediately
driven by money Mark Zuckerberg is a
good example if he'd been driven by
money he'd have taken Yahoo's billion
dollar acquisition offer back in 2006
and most of you probably wouldn't even
recognize his name after we saw how much
it helped founders to have colleagues we
decided to do all of our investing in
batches and gradually we started to have
that YC might make money but by this
time the idea of treating founders like
family and putting their interests first
had become part of YCS culture and while
it's harder to make 116 startups feel
like family than 8 there's still a lot
of that feeling and it might seem
impossible for a group of over 2,000
alumni to feel like family but you'd be
surprised at how much it does and while
this will inevitably sound corny to the

it's mom now why see doesn't end after
demo day the dinners end but we continue
helping the startups for years after
that we still give advice to startups we
funded five or eight years ago startups
need different types of advice sometimes
they're trying to figure out what to

whether to take an acquisition offer or
to fire an employee who isn't working

to give advice about being the social
radar helps me get to the root of the

about startups if you've ever started or

startups behind the scenes are
shows you're laughing because you know
it's true even the most successful ones
they mostly conceal this from the

though this tends to be concealed from

on top of my social radar I now have

one of the most important things I know

there's a group of us who work on events

we did our first startup school in the

see they talk about its novel structure
but that's only half of what YC is the
